content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Kenya Robinson: Well, I was born and raised in Birmingham, Alabama, in a tight-knit neighborhood where everyone knew each other. My parents both worked hard, and while they didn't have a lot of money, they always made sure I had the basics and a good education. I remember walking to school every day with my younger brother, and we'd pass by the same old trees and the same folks who'd wave at us. I was a pretty quiet kid, more interested in books and art than sports or games. My mom used to say I had a way with words, and I guess that's why I ended up going into writing after college. I went to a state school, got my bachelor's in English, and then I just kind of fell into a job at a local publishing house. It's not glamorous, but it's steady, and I like the work. I've never been married, and I don't really see myself getting married anytime soon. I've got a few close friends, and I like to keep things simple. Life hasn't been too dramatic, but I've always tried to make the most of what I've got.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Kenya Robinson: Hmm, thinking back, there was one moment that really shaped my path. I was about 19, just starting my sophomore year in college. I had a choice to either stay close to home and take a job at a local community college to help my parents out financially, or I could take a risk and apply for a scholarship to study at a more prestigious university out of state. I was torn because I didn't want to leave my family, especially after my brother had just started high school. But I also knew that if I didn't push myself, I might never find out what I was truly capable of. In the end, I applied for the scholarship, got accepted, and moved to Ohio. That decision was tough, but it opened up a whole new world for me. I met people I never would have met otherwise, and I was exposed to different ideas and perspectives that really helped me grow. It also made me more confident in my own voice, which is why I ended up pursuing writing. I don't think I would be where I am today if I hadn't made that choice.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Kenya Robinson: I think, in that moment, it was a conscious choice, but it didn't feel like one at the time. I remember sitting in my parents' living room, staring at the scholarship letter, and feeling like I was standing on the edge of something I couldn't quite see. I knew I wanted more for myself, but I also felt guilty about leaving my family behind. It wasn't just about the scholarship—it was about proving to myself that I could take a risk and still come out the other side. I think that's what made it a real choice, even if it felt like it just happened. I had to weigh my fears against my hopes, and in the end, I chose hope.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Kenya Robinson: Absolutely, I think someone or something could have helped. My high school English teacher, Ms. Carter, was one of those people who saw potential in me before I even did. She encouraged me to apply for that scholarship and even wrote a strong letter of recommendation for me. Without her support, I don't know if I would have had the confidence to take that step. Also, the local community center had a mentorship program that I participated in, and the people there helped me think through what I really wanted out of life. It wasn't just about the scholarship—it was about having people who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself. I think that's why I've always tried to pay it forward, even in small ways, like mentoring high school students who are thinking about college.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Kenya Robinson: I don't have a partner or children right now, but my family is still a huge part of my life. My parents are both retired now, and they live just a few blocks away from me in Birmingham. We still see each other often, and I make it a point to visit them at least once a week. My brother is in his late twenties now, and he's working as a mechanic. He's got his own family now—two kids, a daughter and a son. I love being around my niece and nephew; they keep me on my toes, but I also get to see the kind of person I might have become if I had stayed closer to home. I think about that sometimes, but I also know that the path I took has given me a different kind of strength. I'm not sure if I'll ever have a partner or children of my own, but I'm content with the life I've built so far. I've got my family, my work, and a few good friends who keep me grounded.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and made me reflect on how far I've come. It's interesting to look back at my life and see how certain choices, like leaving home for college, shaped who I am today. I never thought I'd be where I am now—writing, working in publishing, and still staying close to my family. It's funny how a single decision can have such a ripple effect. I also realized how much I owe to people like Ms. Carter and the community center; their support gave me the push I needed when I wasn't sure I could take the leap. And even though I don't have a partner or children, I feel fulfilled with my family, friends, and the life I've built. It's not always dramatic, but it's real, and I'm grateful for it.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Kenya Robinson: My immediate family is pretty small—just my parents, my brother, and me. We're all pretty close, even though we've all taken different paths in life. My parents are both pretty traditional, but they've always been supportive of my choices, even when they didn't fully understand them. My dad used to say that as long as I was happy and doing something that made me proud, he was proud of me too. My mom, on the other hand, has always been the one who pushed me to dream bigger. She didn't have the chance to go to college, so she always encouraged me to take every opportunity I could get. I think that's why I ended up in publishing—because she always believed in the power of stories and words. As for my brother, he's more of a hands-on kind of guy, but we get along really well. He's always been my biggest supporter, even when I was the one who left home to chase my dreams. I think that's why I feel so connected to my roots, even though I've been living in Birmingham my whole life and never really left. There's something comforting about knowing that no matter where I go, I always have my family behind me.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Kenya Robinson: Outside of my family, I have a few close friends who have been with me through thick and thin. One of them is Marcus, who I met in college. He's a graphic designer, and we've been friends for over 15 years now. We used to hang out all the time, working on creative projects together, and even though we're both busy with our own lives now, we still make time for each other. Then there's Tiffany, who works in marketing, and we've been best friends since high school. She's the one who always keeps me laughing and reminds me not to take life too seriously. I also have a couple of coworkers at the publishing house who I consider friends—people like Jordan, who's been a mentor to me in the industry, and Lena, who's like a sister to me. We all support each other in different ways, whether it's through advice, encouragement, or just a good cup of coffee and a long conversation. I think having these people in my life has been just as important as my family. They've helped me grow, challenged me when I needed it, and reminded me that I'm not alone in this journey.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Kenya Robinson: I live in a neighborhood here in Birmingham that's a mix of old and new—some of the original brick houses from the 1920s sit right next to newer apartment buildings and small businesses. It's a pretty diverse area, with people from all walks of life, and I like that about it. There's a community garden on the corner that my neighbors and I help maintain, and it's become a little gathering spot for people to chat, share food, or just enjoy the greenery. I live in a two-bedroom apartment on the second floor of a building that's been renovated but still has that old Southern charm. My apartment is cozy, with lots of bookshelves and plants—things I've collected over the years. I love that I can walk to everything: the local library, a few cafes, and even a small bookstore that's been around for decades. It's not the most upscale part of the city, but it feels like home. There's a sense of community here that I really appreciate, and I think that's why I've never felt the need to move away, even though I've had opportunities to do so. I like knowing my neighbors, and I like being part of something bigger than myself.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Kenya Robinson: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a sense of watchfulness in the neighborhood—people know each other, and there's a kind of unspoken agreement to look out for one another. I've never had any real issues with crime, and I think that's partly because of the community spirit. We've got block parties, neighborhood watch meetings, and even a local group that organizes clean-up days. I remember one time when a stranger left their car running in the driveway, and someone from next door came out to check on them. It's those little moments that make me feel like I'm part of something real and caring. I don't think I'd ever want to live somewhere that felt impersonal or unsafe. There's a comfort in knowing that if something happened, someone would be there to help.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Kenya Robinson: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The biggest upside is the community—there's a real sense of belonging that I don't think I'd find in a bigger city. I love being able to walk to the library, grab coffee at the corner café, or just sit on my porch and watch the world go by. But it's not all sunshine and rainbows. Sometimes, the pace of life here can feel a little slow, and I've had to learn to be patient with myself when I want more excitement or new opportunities. There were a few years when I felt stuck in a routine, like I was just going through the motions. But honestly, I think that's part of growing up—figuring out what you want and how to get it. I've also had to deal with the occasional frustration of living in a place that's not always easy to get out of, but I've learned to make the most of what's here. I've found my passion in writing and publishing, and I've built a life that I'm proud of. So even though there are downs, I wouldn't trade this neighborhood for anything. It's home, and I've learned to find beauty in the everyday.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my family and neighborhood mean to me. When talking about my family, I realized how grateful I am for their support and love, even though we've all taken different paths in life. My parents, my brother, and my niece and nephew keep me grounded and remind me of where I came from. It's comforting to know that no matter where I go, I always have them behind me. Then, when I talked about my neighborhood, I felt a deep sense of belonging. It's not the most glamorous place, but it's home—filled with people who care about each other and look out for one another. I've learned to appreciate the small things, like the community garden, the local bookstore, and the friendly faces that make this place feel like family. It's funny how the questions about my family and neighborhood brought it all together, showing me how much I value the connections I've made and the life I've built here in Birmingham.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Kenya Robinson: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, but there's always something different happening. I start my week on Monday with a routine—coffee at the same corner café, a quick walk to the office, and then diving into editing manuscripts and working with the team at the publishing house. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are usually the busiest days, with meetings, deadlines, and sometimes even guest authors coming in for readings or interviews. I love those days because they keep me on my toes and remind me why I chose this line of work. Thursdays are a bit slower, so I often use that time to catch up on reading, visit the library, or meet up with friends for lunch. Fridays are my favorite because I try to leave work early and spend the afternoon with my parents or my brother and his kids. I'll take them to the park, have a picnic, or just sit on the porch and talk. Weekends are more relaxed—I might spend Saturday morning at the community garden helping out, then grab brunch with friends or go to a local bookstore. Sundays are usually for reflection—reading, journaling, or just enjoying the quiet. I've learned to find joy in the rhythm of it all, even if it's not always exciting. It's a life that's not flashy, but it's real, and I'm grateful for it.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Kenya Robinson: I work as an editor at a local publishing house, and I'm usually in the office from Monday to Friday, starting around 9 a.m. and wrapping up by 5:30 p.m. most days. It's a pretty standard 9-to-5 job, but I've learned to make it my own by finding little ways to keep things interesting—like listening to podcasts while I work or taking short walks during lunch breaks. I've been in this role for about six years now, and while it's not the most exciting job in the world, it's steady and gives me the freedom to work on projects that I genuinely care about. I also do some freelance writing on the side, mostly for local magazines and community newsletters. It's not a lot, but it helps me stay connected to the stories of the people around me, which is something I really value. I think that's why I've never felt the need to chase a more high-profile job—this one feels like it's in line with who I am and what I want out of life.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Kenya Robinson: Outside of work, I also have a few routines that keep me grounded. Every evening, I like to take a walk around the neighborhood, especially after dinner. It's a quiet time, and I find it helps me clear my mind and reflect on the day. I also try to read for at least an hour before bed—usually fiction or poetry, something that takes me out of my head and into another world. I've been trying to get back into journaling, too, which I used to do when I was younger. It's a way for me to process my thoughts and track my progress, both personally and professionally. I also make it a point to volunteer at the community center a couple of times a month, helping with literacy programs for kids. It's not a big commitment, but it's something I feel passionate about, and it reminds me of how lucky I am to have had people like Ms. Carter in my life. These little routines might seem simple, but they're what keep me balanced and connected to the people and places that matter most.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Kenya Robinson: Well, recently, I've started waking up a little earlier to get in some quiet time before the day gets going. I used to be a night owl, but I've noticed that when I get up with the sun, I feel more energized and focused. I've also been experimenting with a new routine on weekends—instead of just going to the community garden or the bookstore, I've been trying to explore more of Birmingham. I took a weekend trip to the nearby mountains a few weeks ago, and it was the first time I'd really gotten out of the city in a while. It was nice to see a different side of Alabama, and it reminded me how much I love being close to nature. I think these small changes are helping me stay balanced and keep my life from feeling too predictable. It's funny how something as simple as changing your routine can make such a difference in how you feel about your day.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Kenya Robinson: Actually, I don't have children of my own, but I do spend a lot of time with my brother's kids, my niece and nephew. They're both in elementary school, and their days are pretty structured. My niece, Aisha, is seven and loves reading, just like I did when I was her age. She goes to a public school in the neighborhood, and after school, she usually does homework, then has some time to play or read before dinner. My nephew, Jamal, is five and a bit more into sports and games. He's in a soccer program twice a week, and he also has a weekly art class at the community center. I love being around them because they remind me of what it's like to be curious and full of wonder. I often help them with their homework or take them to the library, and it's amazing how much they've taught me about patience and creativity. Even though I don't have kids of my own, I feel like I've been able to be a part of their lives in a meaningful way, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me really appreciate how much my family, neighborhood, and daily routines shape who I am. It's easy to take these things for granted, but when I think about my parents, my brother, my niece and nephew, and the people in my neighborhood, I realize how much they've supported me throughout my life. My family has always been there, even when I made choices that took me away from them, and my neighborhood gives me a sense of belonging that I didn't expect to find in a place that feels so ordinary. I also realized how important my routines are—whether it's walking in the morning, reading before bed, or volunteering at the community center. These small things keep me grounded and remind me of what matters most. I think it's easy to get caught up in the idea of a dramatic life, but for me, it's the quiet, consistent moments that make life meaningful. I'm grateful for all of it.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Kenya Robinson: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty average—no major issues, but I'm definitely not in peak shape. I used to be more active when I was in college, running a few miles a day and keeping up with the gym, but life has a way of slowing you down. These days, I try to stay as active as I can with my evening walks and the occasional yoga video I do at home. I also make sure to eat pretty well, mostly sticking to home-cooked meals and avoiding too much processed food. I've been dealing with some mild back pain lately, probably from sitting at a desk for so long, but I've started stretching more and using a standing desk at work to help with that. I also try to stay on top of my mental health—journaling, reading, and spending time with family and friends all help me stay grounded. I don't think I'm perfect about it, but I'm learning to listen to my body and take care of myself in the ways that matter most.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Kenya Robinson: For me, staying healthy is a mix of what's easy and what's hard. On the easy side, I love the routine of walking in the evenings—it's something I can do without much effort, and it helps me unwind after a long day. I also find that cooking at home is easier than I used to think, especially now that I've gotten into experimenting with recipes from different cuisines. It's satisfying and keeps me from relying too much on takeout. But the hard part is consistency, especially when it comes to exercise. I know I should be more active, but sometimes the day gets busy, and I end up skipping my workouts or just doing the bare minimum. I also struggle with staying on top of my mental health when life feels overwhelming. I've learned that it's not about being perfect—it's about showing up for myself, even on the days when I don't feel like it. I think that's the key: small, steady habits that add up over time, even if they're not always perfect.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Kenya Robinson: In the past two years, I've had a few health hiccups, nothing too serious, but enough to make me think about how I take care of myself. About a year ago, I started experiencing some persistent lower back pain, which I initially dismissed as just sitting too long at my desk. But after a few months of it getting worse, I finally made an appointment with a physical therapist. Turns out, it was a combination of poor posture and muscle strain from my work routine. The therapist helped me with some stretches and exercises, and I've been using a standing desk more often since then, which has made a big difference. I also had a minor flare-up of my seasonal allergies last spring, which made me more aware of how important it is to stay on top of my health, even with the small things. It's funny, but these little issues have actually been a wake-up call for me to be more intentional about my habits—like making sure I take breaks during the day, staying hydrated, and not skipping my evening walks. I've come to realize that health isn't just about avoiding illness; it's about being proactive and listening to your body when it's trying to tell you something.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Kenya Robinson: Honestly, my health issues haven't really gotten in the way of my work or daily life, but they've made me more aware of how important it is to take care of myself. The back pain did slow me down a bit at first, especially when I was sitting for long periods, but once I started making adjustments—like using the standing desk and stretching more—it became manageable. I didn't have to miss work or make any big changes to my routine, which I'm grateful for. I think the biggest thing is that it made me more intentional about my habits. I used to think I could just power through without taking care of myself, but now I realize that small changes can have a big impact. I've also learned to listen to my body more, which has helped me avoid pushing through when I'm not feeling well. It's not perfect, but it's a reminder that health is something I have to actively maintain, not just something that happens on its own.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Kenya Robinson: Over the past year, I've felt a lot of growth, both personally and professionally. There's been a sense of quiet stability in my life, which I think is something I've been working toward for a while. I've been more intentional about my time, not just with work, but with my family, my friends, and even with myself. I've started setting small goals for the year—like reading more books, getting back into writing short stories, and even trying to write a personal essay about my journey. It's been challenging at times, especially when I feel like I'm not making progress fast enough, but I've learned to be kinder to myself and celebrate the small wins. I also feel more connected to my community than ever before. Volunteering at the community center has become more meaningful to me, and I've started mentoring a few high school students who are thinking about college. It's amazing how much I've learned from them, too—they remind me of what it's like to be young and full of possibilities. I think the past year has been about finding balance and really appreciating the life I've built, even if it's not always perfect. I'm still figuring things out, but I feel more at peace with where I am than I ever have before.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines shape my overall well-being. It's easy to overlook the small things, like walking in the evening or cooking at home, but they've become essential parts of my life that help me stay grounded. I've also come to realize how important it is to listen to my body and make adjustments when needed, whether it's using a standing desk or stretching more throughout the day. These changes, though simple, have made a real difference in how I feel physically and mentally. I used to think of health as something distant or dramatic, but now I see it as something I have to nurture every day—through small, consistent choices. I'm grateful for the wake-up calls, like the back pain and seasonal allergies, because they've reminded me to be more intentional about my habits. I'm learning that health isn't about perfection, but about showing up for myself, even on the hard days.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Kenya Robinson: Honestly, I've had moments where I've felt the weight of anxiety, especially during times when I've felt stuck in a routine or unsure about the direction of my life. There were a few years when I questioned whether I was making the most of my opportunities or if I was just going through the motions. But I've learned to recognize those feelings and not let them define me. I've started talking to a therapist a few times a month, which has been really helpful. It's not that I'm struggling with something severe, but it's about learning how to manage the everyday pressures and expectations that come with life. I think a lot of it has to do with self-compassion—being gentle with myself when I don't feel like I'm on top of everything. I've also found that staying connected to my community, my family, and my creative outlets helps keep me grounded. I don't think I'd ever say I'm completely free of anxiety, but I feel more equipped to handle it now than I did before.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Kenya Robinson: For my family, the past year has been a mix of growth and reflection. My parents are both in their late sixties now, and they've been adjusting to retirement in their own ways. My dad has taken up gardening more seriously, and he's even started selling some of his produce at the local farmers' market. It's been nice to see him find joy in something new, and I've been helping him with the marketing side of it. My mom has been more involved with our neighborhood's community center, especially with the literacy programs. She's always believed in the power of education, and it's heartwarming to see her giving back in a way that aligns with her values. As for my brother and his family, they've been going through their own changes too. My niece, Aisha, is starting to show more interest in writing, and she's been asking me for advice on how to get started. It's amazing how much she's grown, and I can see her becoming the kind of person I always wanted to be. My nephew, Jamal, is still into sports, but he's also starting to explore his creativity through art. It's been a beautiful year for my family, filled with small moments that remind us of how connected we all are, even when life takes us in different directions.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Kenya Robinson: For me, religion or spirituality hasn't played a big role in my life, though I've always been curious about it. I grew up in a household where faith wasn't really discussed, and my parents were more focused on practical things like education and hard work. I respect people who find comfort in their beliefs, and I think spirituality can be a powerful thing for a lot of people. But for me, I've always found meaning in the connections I have with my family, my community, and the small, everyday moments that make life feel full. I don't think of myself as religious, but I do believe in something bigger than myself—like the idea that we're all part of something greater, even if I can't put it into words. I guess I'm more of a person who finds peace in the quiet, in the stories we tell, and in the love and support that surround me. It's not about faith in a higher power for me, but about faith in the people and experiences that shape my life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Kenya Robinson: Honestly, I don't use social media much these days. I've always been more of a private person, and I find that platforms like Facebook or Instagram can sometimes feel more like a performance than a real connection. I used to post a few things back in college, mostly photos of my work or book recommendations, but over time, I started to feel like I was comparing myself to others or getting caught up in things that didn't really matter. Now, I mostly use Facebook to stay in touch with family and a few close friends. I'll check in on my parents' posts or see what my brother's kids are up to, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or engaging with content I don't care about. I think it's important to have boundaries, especially when it comes to how much of your life you share online. For me, it's about quality over quantity—keeping the connections that matter most, without letting the noise of the internet take over.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Kenya Robinson: To be honest, I don't rely on social media for support during tough times. I've always found that the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, and even my coworkers—are enough. When I'm going through something, I tend to reach out to them directly, have a real conversation, and get the kind of support that feels genuine. I think social media can be a double-edged sword. On one hand, it can connect you to people who understand what you're going through, but on the other hand, it can also make you feel more isolated if you're just scrolling through someone else's highlight reel. I've seen friends get caught up in that, and it's not something I want to deal with. For me, it's about keeping things simple and relying on the people who are already in my life. If I ever need support, I know I can count on them, and that's more than enough.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how my health and mental well-being have shaped my recent experiences and how I navigate life. It's interesting how something as simple as back pain or seasonal allergies can be a wake-up call to reevaluate my habits and priorities. I used to think of health as something distant or dramatic, but now I see it as something I have to nurture every day—through small, consistent choices. At the same time, I've come to terms with the fact that anxiety and moments of self-doubt are part of life, and it's not about eliminating them, but learning how to manage them with self-compassion and support from the people I care about. I've also realized how much my family and community contribute to my sense of stability and purpose, even when I'm not sure about the direction of my own life. These reflections have helped me feel more grounded and reminded me that it's okay to take things one step at a time.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Kenya Robinson: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have actually gone down a bit, which is something I didn't expect. I think it's because I've been more intentional about how I spend my time and what I prioritize. I used to worry a lot about not being ambitious enough or not making the most of my opportunities, but I've come to realize that my life doesn't need to be defined by big, dramatic moments. I've started using journaling more consistently as a way to process my thoughts, and it's helped me quiet the noise in my head. I also find that when I'm surrounded by the people I love—whether it's my parents, my brother, or my friends—it makes everything feel more manageable. I've learned to take things one step at a time, and that's given me a sense of calm I didn't have before. I still have days when I feel overwhelmed, but I'm not as quick to let those feelings take over as I used to be. It's like I've built a little buffer between myself and the stress, and that's been a real gift.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Kenya Robinson: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. I live in a two-bedroom apartment, and the rent is about $1,200 a month. That's a big chunk of my income, but I've been lucky that my job at the publishing house has been stable. Groceries are another thing—I try to cook at home as much as possible, but with my evening walks and the occasional coffee runs, it adds up. I also have a car payment, insurance, and a few other bills like internet and phone. I don't spend much on entertainment or luxury items, but I do set aside some money each month for books and maybe a nice meal out with friends. I've been trying to be more mindful of my spending, especially since I want to save a little for the future. It's not always easy, but I've learned to prioritize what really matters—like my family, my health, and the things that bring me joy.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Kenya Robinson: Last month, our household spent around $2,800, which is pretty much in line with what we usually spend. Rent is the biggest chunk, as I mentioned, and then groceries come in a close second. I try to keep things simple—buying in bulk when I can, cooking at home, and avoiding unnecessary expenses. Transportation is another regular expense, mostly for gas and maintenance on my car. I don't have a lot of debt, which helps, and I've been pretty good about setting aside a little each month for savings, even if it's just a few hundred dollars. I think the key for me has always been prioritizing what matters most—my family, my health, and the things that bring me joy. I don't need a lot to be happy, and I've learned to be content with what I have. It's not always easy, but I've come to see that financial stability isn't about having everything—it's about having enough to live the life you want, and I feel like I'm doing that.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Kenya Robinson: We rent our home, actually. I live in a two-bedroom apartment on the second floor of a building that's been around for a while but has been nicely renovated. It's not the most expensive place in the neighborhood, but it's comfortable and has everything I need. I've been renting for a few years now, and I don't see myself buying a home anytime soon. I like the flexibility that renting gives me, especially since I don't know where life might take me in the next few years. Plus, with the way the real estate market is, I think it's smarter to keep my money liquid for now. I've been lucky that my job has been stable, so I can afford to rent without too much stress, and I don't mind the idea of staying put in a place that feels like home.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Kenya Robinson: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, just like the seasons. In the winter, heating costs went up a bit, and I had to be more mindful of turning the thermostat down to save money. I also noticed that my grocery bills tend to increase around the holidays, especially when I'm buying extra snacks or treats for my niece and nephew. Then there's the summer, when I start using more electricity for fans and air conditioning, and I also spend a little more on outdoor activities like picnics or weekend trips to the park. School-related expenses come into play too—when my brother's kids are in full-time school, I end up spending a bit more on supplies or special events like field trips or school dances. But overall, I've been pretty consistent with my budget, and I try to adjust as needed without letting it stress me out. It's all about finding a balance and making sure I'm not overspending on things that don't really matter.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me think a lot about how my family and my approach to social media shape my sense of well-being. It's amazing how much my parents and siblings have grown in their own ways, and seeing them find joy and purpose in their lives has been a source of comfort and inspiration for me. I've also come to appreciate how I don't need social media to feel connected or supported. My real-life relationships—with my family, friends, and coworkers—are what truly matter, and they've always been there for me. I used to worry about missing out on something by not being more active online, but now I see that the quiet, meaningful connections I have are enough. It's a reminder that life doesn't need to be loud or flashy to be fulfilling. I'm grateful for the people in my life and the simple, real ways we stay connected.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Kenya Robinson: I do save, though it's not a huge amount. I have a small savings account that I try to contribute to every month, even if it's just $50 or $100. It's more about building a habit than aiming for a specific number. I also keep some money in a separate jar at home for unexpected expenses, like car repairs or medical bills. I think it's important to have a little cushion, even if it's not a lot. I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about big goals—it can be about small, consistent choices. I used to think I needed to be wealthy to feel secure, but now I see that it's more about being prepared for life's little surprises. I'm not perfect at it, but I'm trying to be more intentional about my money, and that gives me a sense of control I didn't have before.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Kenya Robinson: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for any big purchases, honestly. I think it's because I've learned the value of being prepared, especially after dealing with some minor health issues and the occasional unexpected expense. I don't see myself buying a home anytime soon, so I haven't been saving for that specifically. Instead, I've been focusing on building a small emergency fund, just in case something comes up—like a car repair or a sudden medical bill. I also set aside a little each month for personal goals, like buying a new book or taking a weekend trip. It's not about having a lot, but about feeling secure in the little things. I've come to realize that saving doesn't have to be about grand plans—it can be about showing up for yourself, even in small ways, and that gives me a sense of peace I didn't have before.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Kenya Robinson: I work as an editor at a local publishing house, and my main responsibilities involve reviewing and refining manuscripts before they're published. I spend a lot of time reading, analyzing the flow and clarity of the writing, and working closely with authors to help them improve their work. I also coordinate with designers and marketers to ensure that the final product meets the standards of the company. One of the most important parts of my job is being a good listener—whether it's understanding an author's vision or helping them find their voice. I've always loved the idea that words have the power to change people, and I feel lucky to be in a position where I can help others share their stories. It's not always easy, especially when you're dealing with tight deadlines or difficult feedback, but I've learned to find satisfaction in the small victories, like seeing a book I worked on hit the shelves or receiving a thank-you note from an author. I think that's what keeps me going—it's not just about the work itself, but about the impact it can have on others.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Kenya Robinson: I usually work around 40 hours a week, which is pretty standard for my job. I'm in the office from Monday to Friday, starting at 9 a.m. and typically leaving around 5:30 p.m., though I sometimes stay a little later if I'm working on a deadline or need to finish up some edits. I've learned to be efficient with my time, and I try to leave a little buffer at the end of the day so I don't feel rushed. I also make it a point to take regular breaks throughout the day—whether it's stepping outside for a few minutes, grabbing a coffee, or just stretching at my desk. I think it's important to stay present and not let work consume all of my time. I've been lucky that my job doesn't require me to work weekends or late nights too often, which gives me the flexibility to spend time with my family and friends. It's not always perfect, but I've come to appreciate the balance I have now.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Kenya Robinson: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on one role at a time, which has helped me stay grounded and not spread myself too thin. That said, I do some freelance writing on the side, mostly for local magazines and community newsletters. It's not a full-time gig, but it keeps me connected to the stories of the people around me and gives me a creative outlet outside of my editing work. I've found that having a secondary project, even if it's just a few hours a week, helps me stay inspired and reminds me why I chose this line of work in the first place. It's not about making extra money—it's about staying engaged with the world and the people in it. I think that's why I've never felt the need to take on more than I can handle. I've learned to find satisfaction in the work I do, even if it's not always glamorous or high-profile.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my stress levels, emotional coping strategies, and financial stability have all played a role in shaping my sense of well-being. It's interesting how reducing stress hasn't come from big life changes, but from small, intentional habits like journaling and spending time with loved ones. I've also come to appreciate how my financial situation, while not extravagant, gives me the freedom to live a life that feels meaningful and grounded. I used to worry about not having enough or not being ambitious enough, but now I see that contentment comes from knowing what truly matters—family, health, and the simple joys of everyday life. It's a reminder that I don't need to chase perfection or dramatic moments to feel fulfilled. I'm learning to find peace in the quiet, the routine, and the people who support me every day.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Kenya Robinson: In total, my household made around $3,200 in the past month. That comes from my full-time job at the publishing house, which pays a steady salary, and the freelance writing I do on the side. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover my expenses and even allow me to set aside a little for savings. I've always believed that financial stability doesn't come from having more than you need, but from knowing exactly what you need and being able to provide it. I'm grateful for the work I do and the flexibility it gives me. It's not about chasing wealth—it's about finding contentment in what I have and making sure I can support the people I care about, whether that's my family, my friends, or even the community I'm part of. I think that's what makes life meaningful for me: not the numbers on a paycheck, but the ability to live with purpose and peace.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Kenya Robinson: I've been at my current job at the publishing house for about six years now, and it's been a journey. When I first started, I was just out of college, still figuring out what I wanted to do with my life. I remember feeling a bit lost, like I was just going through the motions. But over time, I've grown into the role and found a real sense of purpose in it. The benefits of the job are pretty standard—health insurance, paid time off, and a few holidays. I also get a few days of sick leave, which has been helpful, especially when I've had to deal with my back pain or seasonal allergies. I think the best part of the job, though, is the flexibility. I can usually work from home a couple of days a week if I need to, and the company is pretty supportive of employees who want to balance work with personal life. I've also had the chance to work on some really meaningful projects—books that have touched people, stories that have made a difference. It's not always easy, but I feel lucky to be in a place where I can do work that matters, even if it's not always in the spotlight.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Kenya Robinson: My relationships at work are pretty good overall. I have a manager, Ms. Delgado, who's been with the company for a while and has a lot of experience. She's fair, supportive, and doesn't micromanage, which I really appreciate. I think we have a mutual respect—she knows I'm reliable and I know she's someone I can trust to give me honest feedback. As for my coworkers, I've been lucky to work with a team that's both professional and friendly. There's Jordan, who I mentioned earlier, and he's been a mentor to me in the industry. He's always willing to share his knowledge and help me grow. Then there's Lena, who's like a sister to me—she's the one who keeps the office light and fun, and I don't know what I'd do without her. We all have our own quirks, but we get along well and support each other through the ups and downs of the job. I think that's what makes this workplace feel like a real community, even if it's just for eight hours a day.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Kenya Robinson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a fair amount of flexibility, which I really appreciate. I usually start at 9 a.m. and finish around 5:30 p.m., though I sometimes stay a little later if I'm working on a deadline or need to wrap up some edits. The company allows me to work from home a couple of days a week, which is a huge perk, especially on days when I need to rest my back or just want to avoid the commute. I also have the option to adjust my hours a bit if I need to, as long as I'm meeting my deadlines. It's not a rigid 9-to-5 in the traditional sense, but it's structured enough that I can plan my days and still have time for my family, my walks, and my other routines. I think that balance is what makes the job sustainable for me—it gives me the stability I need without feeling like I'm trapped in a box.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Kenya Robinson: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation. It's not extravagant, and I know there are people out there with more money and more opportunities, but I also know that I have enough to live the life I want. I don't need a lot to be happy—I have my family, my work, and the little things that make life feel full. I've learned to be grateful for what I have instead of always chasing more. There are days when I worry about the future, especially with things like healthcare costs or unexpected expenses, but I've also learned to be proactive about saving and budgeting. I think the key for me has always been knowing what I need versus what I want, and I've come to accept that I don't need to have everything to feel secure. I'm not perfect at it, but I'm trying to be intentional with my money, and that gives me a sense of peace I didn't have before.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me think a lot about how my financial habits, work schedule, and savings mindset shape my sense of stability. It's interesting how my bills fluctuate with the seasons and life events, but I've learned to adjust without letting it cause too much stress. I used to worry about not having enough or not being ambitious enough, but now I see that contentment comes from knowing what I need and being able to provide it. My job gives me a predictable schedule with enough flexibility to balance work and life, and I've come to appreciate that. I also realize that saving doesn't have to be about big goals—it can be about small, consistent choices that give me peace of mind. I'm learning to find satisfaction in what I have rather than always chasing more, and that gives me a sense of control and purpose that I didn't have before.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Kenya Robinson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked at a local factory for over twenty years, and my mom was a school administrator at the middle school I attended. They both had stable jobs that allowed us to live comfortably, though we never had a lot of extra money. I remember my mom working late into the evenings sometimes, grading papers or planning lessons, and my dad coming home tired but always making sure we had dinner ready. They both put in long hours, but they always made time for us, even if it was just sitting down for a meal or helping with homework. I think that's why I've always valued hard work and education so much—it wasn't just something they taught me, it was something they lived every day. I also remember how proud they were of me when I got into college, even though it was a big step for them to let me go. It's funny how their sacrifices shaped my path, even if they didn't realize it at the time.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Kenya Robinson: My dad worked at a local factory that manufactured automotive parts, and his most important duties involved operating heavy machinery and ensuring that production lines ran smoothly. He was a hard worker, always showing up on time and taking pride in his job, even when the work was repetitive or physically demanding. My mom, on the other hand, was a school administrator at the middle school I attended. Her days were filled with meetings, scheduling, and making sure that the school ran like a well-oiled machine. She was the one who handled discipline issues, coordinated events, and made sure teachers had what they needed to do their jobs. Both of them had their own challenges, but they always made it clear that education and responsibility were important values to live by. I remember watching my mom work late into the evenings, grading papers and planning lessons, and my dad coming home exhausted but always making sure we had dinner ready. They both put in long hours, but they always made time for us, even if it was just sitting down for a meal or helping with homework. I think that's why I've always valued hard work and education so much—it wasn't just something they taught me, it was something they lived every day.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Kenya Robinson: My dad worked for a company called Southern Auto Parts, which was a local manufacturer based in Birmingham. They made everything from engine components to brake systems, and my dad was one of the lead operators on the assembly line. It was a tough job—long hours, hot environment, and the kind of work that required you to be on your feet all day. But he always said that the work had its own kind of dignity, and he took pride in knowing that the parts he helped make went into cars that people relied on every day. My mom worked for the Birmingham Public Schools system, and she was the assistant principal at the middle school I attended. Her job involved a lot of behind-the-scenes work—scheduling, budgeting, and making sure that the school stayed compliant with state regulations. But she also had to handle the more visible parts of the job, like dealing with parent-teacher conferences, student discipline, and organizing school events. I remember her telling me once that being an administrator wasn't just about managing people—it was about managing the whole ecosystem of a school, and that meant being ready for anything, from a sudden budget cut to a student in crisis. Both of them worked for businesses that were rooted in the community, and I think that's why they always emphasized the importance of giving back, even when times were tough.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Kenya Robinson: A few years from now, I hope I'm still living in this neighborhood, still surrounded by the people and places that have shaped me. I hope I'm still working in publishing, maybe even in a slightly more senior role, but not because I'm chasing titles or recognition—I hope it's because I'm still passionate about the work and the stories we get to share with the world. I also hope I'm still mentoring young people, whether it's high school students thinking about college or my niece, Aisha, who's already showing an interest in writing. I want to be someone who can look back and say I made a difference, even in small ways. I don't know if I'll ever have a partner or children of my own, but I hope I'm still close to my family, still having those Sunday dinners with my parents, and still being the kind of person who finds joy in the quiet moments—the smell of coffee in the morning, the sound of laughter from my niece and nephew, or the feeling of walking through the neighborhood with a book in hand. I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still finding meaning in the life I've built here in Birmingham.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Kenya Robinson: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my friends, or the people in my neighborhood. I think we're all just trying to find our place in the world, and for me, that place has always been rooted in the relationships I've built. I value the quiet moments, like sitting on my porch with a book, or having a real conversation with someone who truly listens. I value the work I do, not because it's perfect or glamorous, but because it allows me to be part of something bigger than myself. I value the lessons I've learned from my parents, who taught me the importance of hard work and education, and from my community, who showed me the power of support and belonging. I value the fact that I've been given the chance to grow, to make mistakes, and to keep trying. And I value the simple truth that life doesn't have to be dramatic or extravagant to be meaningful. It's the love, the stories, the small joys, and the people who keep me grounded that I hold most dear.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my financial stability, work schedule, and relationships at work all contribute to the sense of balance I've built in my life. It's interesting how my income, while not extravagant, gives me the freedom to live with purpose and support the people I care about. I've come to appreciate that my job isn't about chasing wealth or recognition, but about finding fulfillment in the work I do and the connections I make with others. My work schedule, with its predictable structure and flexibility, allows me to maintain a rhythm that supports both my professional and personal life. And my relationships with my manager and coworkers remind me that a good workplace is more than just a job—it's a community where I can grow, learn, and feel supported. I'm grateful for the stability and meaning I've found in these areas, even if they don't always feel dramatic or exciting.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and gratitude. It's amazing how much my life has been shaped by the small, consistent choices I've made—whether it was choosing to leave home for college, staying connected with my family, or finding joy in the quiet moments of everyday life. I've come to realize that my story isn't about grand moments or dramatic turns, but about the people, routines, and values that have grounded me over the years. I'm grateful for the support of my parents, my brother, my friends, and the community I live in, all of whom have played a role in shaping who I am today. I've also learned that health, financial stability, and emotional well-being don't have to be perfect, but they can be nurtured through intention and care. This interview has reminded me that my life, while not always flashy, is full of meaning, and I'm proud of the person I've become.
